text: I voted ‘NO’ on the Republican budget plan because it threatens access to healthcare for millions. By cutting Medicaid and driving up costs, Trump and House Republicans have already put families, hospitals, and community health centers in crisis. Their plan is less about governing and more about forcing a shutdown and blaming Democrats.

While I condemn his violent murder, this resolution sought to elevate Charlie Kirk as a role model.

I could not support in good conscience.

This past Saturday, I took part in commemorating the 150th anniversary of the Clinton Massacre.

The Clinton Massacre was a violent attack in 1875 when a group of white men tried to scare and hurt Black people who were peacefully gathering to vote and participate in politics. 

Thank you to the community, organizers, descendants, and leaders who came together to remember, reflect, and reclaim this story.

Trump’s “Big, Ugly Law,” signed on July 4, 2025, slashes more than $880 billion from Medicaid over 10 years. That’s not beautiful, it’s cruel. The damage won’t be felt equally; rural communities in poorer states like Mississippi will feel it the most.

I recently heard from a constituent who can’t afford a doctor’s visit, can barely eat, and has just $10,000 to last the rest of her life. She’s not alone. Medicare and Medicaid are essential programs, and I will fight to protect them.

If you are starting to feel the impacts of this law, please share your story by visiting my website: https://t.co/ihcEik1Iss

Thousands in Mississippi’s 2nd Congressional District are at risk of losing health insurance coverage starting in 2026 due to new federal mandates in the Republicans’ “Big, Ugly Law”.

This means more uninsured families, more ER visits, and more hospital closures. Mississippi and MS02 have some of the highest poverty and health disparities in the country.

We can’t afford cuts to Medicare & Medicaid.

60 years ago, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare and Medicaid into law, transforming health care in America. 

In Mississippi, Medicaid covers 667,000 people, including half of all children and 60% of births. 

In MS-02, 1 in 4 residents rely on Medicare, the highest rate in the state.

Imagine working hard to earn student loan forgiveness and watching it being stripped away without warning. This is the reality for many students in America. Students who deserve consistency, transparency, and truth.

Don’t let Trump fool you. The “Big Ugly Bill” did not eliminate federal taxes on Social Security benefits. Up to 85% of Social Security benefits remain taxable based on income.

It is important to stay informed and alert, because Americans need truth, not false headlines when it comes to their hard-earned benefits.

https://t.co/n2b5nWCxmd
